sec_questions: In the given amine, all three hydrogens of NH3 are replaced by one each of the propyl, ethyl, and methyl groups, and is a tertiary or 3° amine. Since all three groups are alkyl and different, it is an aliphatic mixed amine.
The compound shown is a _______ amine.
Only one hydrogen atom is replaced by an aromatic group, in which the nitrogen is directly linked to the sp2 hybridised carbon of the benzene ring. Hence, it is a primary aromatic aryl amine.
Which of the following best describes the amine (CH3CH2)3N?
All three hydrogen atoms of ammonia are replaced by the same ethyl group in (CH3CH2)3N, which makes is a 3° simple amine.
Which of the following is a primary arylalkyl amine?

Since it should be primary, it should have an alkyl/aryl group attached to the NH2 molecule, and because it is arylalkyl, the nitrogen should be linked to a sp3 hybridised benzyl carbon rather than to an aryl carbon.
Since the compound consists of a benzene ring, it invariably is an aromatic amine. Moreover, it also contains an alkyl methyl group beside the phenyl group and this makes it a mixed amine.
Which of the following is the IUPAC name of the compound in which one hydrogen of ammonia is replaced by an ethyl group?

Ethylamine and aminoethane are the names of CH3CH2NH2 according to the common system and second system respectively. In the IUPAC system, the naming is done by replacing the ‘e’ of the alkane by amine.
Which of the following names of amines belong strictly to the common system?

In the common system, aliphatic amines are named by prefixing the alkyl group to amine, i.e., alkylamine. In the case of two different alkyl groups, it is named by listing the alkyl groups in alphabetical order before the word amine, just like in ethylmethylamine. Aniline is a common name but is also accepted by IUPAC.
Which of the following names of aromatic amines does not belong to the common naming system?

In the common system, the aromatic amines have special names derived from the basic compound aniline and depending upon the type of substituent group. The prefixes o-, m- and p- are used to depict the position of the substituent in a common system. Whereas, the number position of carbon is used in the IUPAC system.
What is the correct common name of H2N-CH2-CH2-NH2?

In this compound, more than one amino group is present at different positions in the parent chain. Both the amino groups are given equal importance and none of them is considered a substituent on the other. The prefix di- is used before amine, and since it is a disubstituted ethane, it is referred to as ethylene.
What is the correct IUPAC name of H2N-(CH2)5-NH2?

The parent carbon chain consists of five atoms with one amino group at each end, i.e., the first and fifth carbon. The prefix di is used to indicate the two amino groups and the letter ‘e’ of the suffix part of pentane is retained. Hence, the name pentane-1,5-diamine.
Identify the incorrect name of the shown compound.

The shown compound is a primary amine and hence the locant N cannot be used as it is invalid. The amino group is attached to the second carbon of the propyl group (which is also known as isopropyl substituent).
Which of the following is the correct IUPAC name of (CH3)3N?

The IUPAC name of (CH3)3-N is N,N-Dimethylmethanamine.

The compound is a tertiary amine with three methyl substituents. One of the methyl groups is considered as the parent chain with the N atom and the other two act as substituents. These are represented by N, N- as they are the same groups and are directly attached to the nitrogen atom.
What is the IUPAC name of the following compound?

This is a tertiary amine with two identical alkyl substituents (ethyl group) and one butyl group which acts as the major chain. The prefix N,N-Di is used for the ethyl groups and this collective group is attached at the first carbon of the butyl group.
Identify the incorrect name of the aromatic primary amine with the formula C7H9N.

Since it is an aromatic compound, the phenyl group C6H5 has to present with CH4N. Since it is a primary amine, the group NH2 can be separated leaving us with CH2. So, the formula of the compound is C6H5CH2NH2, which is benzylamine. Benzenamine has the formula C6H5NH2.
Hexamethylenediamine is named as __________ in the IUPAC system.
The formula is NH2-(CH2)6-NH2 which is the chain of 6 carbon atoms and two amino groups at the ends of the chain, i.e., first and sixth carbon. This type of substitution is named hexamethylene.
Which of the following amines is not a gas?
Lower members of aliphatic amines exist as gases at ordinary temperatures. The higher members with three or more carbon atoms are liquid and still higher ones are solid.
What is the characteristic odour of relatively lower aliphatic amines?
Most of the amines have an unpleasant odour. The smell of lower amines is similar to that of ammonia with a fishy odour.
Which of the following best describes aniline in pure form?
Aniline and other aryl amines are usually colourless, but they become coloured on storage due to atmospheric oxygen. Aniline develops a yellow to brown colour due to this reason.
The intermolecular hydrogen bonds, if any, in amines is formed between _______.
Primary and secondary amines are involved in intermolecular molecular hydrogen bonding between the nitrogen of one and the hydrogen of another molecule.
What is the correct order of boiling points of the isomeric amines where A=ethylmethylamine, B=propylamine and C=trimethylamine?

A, B, and C are respectively the 2°, 1°, and 3° isomers of the compound C3H9N. Primary and secondary amines have two and one hydrogen atom respectively for hydrogen bonding. Whereas, tertiary amines do not have intermolecular association due to the absence of H for hydrogen bonding.
Which of the following has a lower boiling point than ethanamine?

All given compounds have similar molecular masses and can be compared. Ethanamine has a higher boiling point than propane because it is a polar molecule and forms intermolecular hydrogen bonds. However, it has a lower boiling point than ethanal, ethanol, and methanoic acid as the O-H bonds in these compounds is more polar than the N-H bond in ethanamine. This makes the hydrogen bonds stronger.
If the boiling point of diethylamine is 329 K, predict the boiling point of ethyldimethylamine.

Diethylamine is a 2° amine whereas, ethyldimethylamine is a 3° amine. In 3° amines, there are no hydrogen atoms available for intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Therefore, the tertiary amines have the lowest boiling point among the primary and secondary counterparts.
If the boiling point of n-C4H9NH2 is 351 K, what will be the boiling point of n-C4H9OH?

Alcohols have higher boiling points than amines of comparable molecular masses. This is because the electronegativity of N is lower than that of O, which results in the OH bond in alcohols being more polar and hence stronger (in hydrogen bonding) than the N-H bond in amines.
If A is the boiling point of propanamine and B is the boiling point of butanamine, what is the correct relation between the two?
Butanamine is a larger molecule than ethanamine. As the carbon chain increases, the magnitude of van der Waals forces increases resulting in the increase in boiling point.
Which of the following amines are insoluble in water?

Lower aliphatic amines are soluble in water as they easily form hydrogen bonds with water molecules. Higher amines containing six or more carbon atoms are insoluble in water due to a large hydrophobic alkyl/aryl part. Therefore, aniline is insoluble in water.
If ‘x’ ml of butan-1amine and ‘y’ ml of butan-1-ol is completely soluble in 100ml of water each, what is the relation between x and y?

Alcohols are more polar than amines of comparable molecular masses and form stronger intermolecular hydrogen bonds with water. Therefore, the solubility of butan-1-ol is more than that of butan-1-amine.
Aniline is insoluble in which of the following solvents?

Aromatic amines have a very large hydrocarbon part (benzene ring) which tends to retard the formation of hydrogen bonds with water. However, they are soluble in organic solvents like ethers, alcohols, and benzene.
Which of the following is least soluble in water?

Lower amines are more soluble because of the smaller hydrophobic alkyl part. Also, alcohols and carboxylic acids have a higher solubility than amines because of the greater polarity of the OH bond than the NH bond.
Amines behave as nucleophiles due to the presence of an unshared pair of electrons on the N atom. This also makes them proton acceptors and reacts with acids to form salts.
Which of the following is associated with a decrease in the pKb value of amines?

The basic strength of amines is expressed in terms of the dissociation constant Kb. The greater the Kb value, the stronger the base. It is more commonly expressed as pKb=-logKb. Hence smaller the value of pKb, the more is the basic strength of the amine.
The second order rate constant is usually expressed as:

Let us consider a second order reaction: \(A \rightarrow B\)

Rate Law for this Reaction is given by: Rate \(=\mathrm{k}[\mathrm{A}]^2\)

\(\because\) Unit of Rate of Reaction is mol litre \({ }^{-1} \mathrm{sec}^{-1}\) and Unit of Concentration is mol litre \({ }^{-1}\)

\(\therefore\) Unit of Rate constant is \(\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\) litre sec \({ }^{-1}\)
For which of the following represents the expression for three/fourth life of reaction?

As we know, for a first order reaction,

\({t}=\frac{2.303}{{\mathrm{k}}} \log \frac{{a}}{({a}-{x})}\)

If \(t=t_{\frac{3 }{ 4}} ; x=\frac{3 a }{ 4}\)

\(\therefore {t}_{\frac{3 }{ 4}}=\frac{2.303}{{\mathrm{k}}} \log \frac{{a}}{{a}-\frac{3 a }{ 4}}=\frac{2.303}{\mathrm{k}} \log 4\)

The rate constant of a reaction increases by five times on increase in temperature from \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(52^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). The value of activation energy in \(\mathrm{kJ} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}\) is:

(Rounded off to the nearest integer)

\(\left[R=8.314 \mathrm{JK}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\right]\)

Let, the rate constants be \(\mathrm{k}_{52^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}\) and \(\mathrm{k}_{27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}\)

According to the question,

\(\frac{\mathrm{k}_{52^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}}{\mathrm{k}_{27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}}=5\)

From Arrhenius equation,

\(\operatorname{ln}\left\{\frac{\mathrm{k}_{T_2}}{\mathrm{k}_{T_1}}\right\}=\frac{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\mathrm{R}}\left\{\frac{1}{\mathrm{~T}_1}-\frac{1}{\mathrm{~T}_2}\right\} \)

\(\Rightarrow \ln (5)=\frac{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\mathrm{R}}\left\{\frac{1}{300}-\frac{1}{325}\right\} \)

\(\Rightarrow 2.303 \log (5)=\frac{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\mathrm{R}}\left\{\frac{1}{300}-\frac{1}{325}\right\} \)

\(\Rightarrow \frac{2.303 \times 0.7 \times 8.314 \times 300 \times 325}{25}=\mathrm{E}_a \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a}}=52271.69 \mathrm{~J} / \mathrm{mol} \)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a}}=52.272 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\)

Increasing the temperature of a system increases the average kinetic energy of its constituent particles. As the average kinetic energy increases, the particles move faster and collide more frequently per unit time and possess greater energy when they collide. Both of these factors increase the reaction rate.

\(K E_{\text {avg }}=\left[\overline{\frac{1}{2} m v^2}\right]=\frac{3}{2} k T\)
A first order reaction is \(50 \%\) completed in 20 minutes at \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and in \(5 \mathrm{~min}\) at \(47^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). The energy of activation of the reaction is:

We know that half life for first order reaction is:

\(\mathrm{t}_{\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{0.693}{\mathrm{k}}\)

So, rate constant at \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

\(\mathrm{k}_1=\frac{0.693}{20} \mathrm{~min}^{-1}\)

Rate constant at \(47^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

\(\mathrm{k}_2=\frac{0.693}{5} \mathrm{~min}^{-1}\)

Arrhenius equation:

\(k=A e^{\left(-\frac{E_a}{R T}\right)}\)

Ratio of \(k_1\) to \(k_2\) is equal to:

\(\frac{k_1}{k_2}=e^{\left[\frac{E_a}{R}\left(\frac{T_1-T_2}{T_1 T_2}\right)\right]}\)

Taking natural log on both sides, we get:

\(\ln \frac{\mathrm{k}_1}{\mathrm{k}_2}=\left[\frac{\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a}}}{\mathrm{R}}\left(\frac{\mathrm{T}_1-\mathrm{T}_2}{\mathrm{~T}_1 \mathrm{~T}_2}\right)\right]\)

\(\ln \frac{1}{4}=\left[\frac{E_a}{8.314}\left(\frac{300-320}{300 \times 320}\right)\right]\)

On solving, we get:

\(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a}}=55.14 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\)
An increase in the rate of a reaction for a rise in temperature is due to:
Increase in the number of activated molecules

An increase in the rate of a reaction for a rise in temperature is due to  increase in collision frequency, shortening of mean free path and increase in the number of activated molecules.

Increasing the temperature increases reaction rates because of the disproportionately large increase in the number of high energy collisions. It is only these collisions (possessing at least the activation energy for the reaction) which result in a reaction.
In a certain reaction, \(10 \%\) of the reactant decomposes in one hour, \(20 \%\) in two hours, \(30 \%\) in three hours, and so on. The dimension of the velocity constant (rate constant) is:

For zero-order reaction rate is independent of concentration. Therefore, it is a zero-order reaction. So, dimension of \(k=\mathrm{m o l} \mathrm{~L}^{-1} \mathrm{hr}^{-1}\)

For zero order: \({t}=\frac{x}{k}\) or \(k=\frac{x}{t}\)

If \({t}={t}_{10 \%}=60 \min, x=10\),

Then, \(r=\frac{-10}{1}=10\) mol L \(^{-1} h r^{-1}\)

If \({t}={t}_{20 \%}=120 \min , x=20\),

Then, \(r=\frac{20}{2}=10\) mol L \({ }^{-1} h r^{-1}\)

Similarly, for \(30 \%\) and so on.

Thus, the reaction is of zero order.

If a reaction, \(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{C}\) is exothermic to the extent of \(30 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\) and the forward reaction has an activation energy \(70 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\), the activation energy for the reverse reaction is (in \(\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\) ):

\(\Delta \mathrm{H}=-30 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\), means that the reactants are at an energy of \(30 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\), higher than the products.

The activation energy of the forward reaction is equal to the difference in energy between the reactants and the activated complex.

So, the activation energy of the backward reaction would be the sum of the energy difference between the reactants and the products and the activation energy of the forward reaction i.e.,

\(30+70=100 \mathrm{~kJ} / \mathrm{mol}\)
In an endothermic reaction, \(\Delta H\) represents change in enthalpy of a reaction in \(\mathrm{KJ} / \mathrm{mol}\), the minimum value for energy of activation will be?

Ea is the energy that must be possessed by the molecules in excess to the average energy at a given temperature to enter a chemical reaction. Relation between activation energy and enthalpy of a reversible reaction.

If the reaction is endothermic in forward direction, then

\(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a} \text { (backwards) }}=\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a} \text { (forward) }}+\Delta \mathrm{H}\)

If the reaction is exothermic in forward direction

\(\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a} \text { (backward) }}=\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{a} \text { (forward) }}+\Delta \mathrm{H}\)

For an endothermic reaction, where \(\Delta \mathrm{H}\) represents the enthalpy of the reaction in \(\mathrm{KJ} \mathrm{mol}^{-1}\), the minimum value for the energy of activation will be slightly more than \(\Delta \mathrm{H}\).

For a reaction: \(3 \mathrm{~A} \rightarrow\) products

It is found that the rate of reaction doubles when the concentration of \(A\) is increased by four times. What is the order of the reaction?

Rate \(=k[\text { Reactant }]^n\)

Here:

\(r_1=k[A]^n \ldots \ldots \text { (1) } \)

\(r_2=2 r_1=k[4 A]^n \ldots \ldots \text { (2) }\)

where \(r_1\) is the rate of the reaction

Now dividing equation (2) by equation (1), we get,

\(2=[4]^n \)

\(\Rightarrow n=\frac{1}{2}\)
It is the minimum amount of energy it takes to start a chemical reaction.
It is the maximum amount of energy it takes to start a chemical reaction.
It is the intermediate compound in a chemical reaction.
It is the energy needed for an exothermic reaction.

Activation Energy: The minimum energy which must be available to a chemical system with potential reactants to result in a chemical reaction.

Activation energy may also be defined as the minimum energy required to start a chemical reaction. The activation energy of a reaction is usually denoted by Ea and given in units of kilojoules per mole \((\mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{mol})\) or kilocalories per mole \((\mathrm{kcal} / \mathrm{mol})\).

The experimental data for the reaction, \(2 \mathrm{~A}+\mathrm{B}_2 \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{AB}\), is as follows:

Expt. No.

[A]
(mol L−1)

[B2​]
(mol L−1)

Rate
(mol L−1s−1)

1.

0.50

0.50

1.6×10−4

2.

0.50

1.00

3.2×10−4

3.

1.00

1.00

3.2×10−4

Write the most probable equation for the rate of reaction giving reason for your answer.

From an examination of above data, it is clear that when the concentration of \(\mathrm{B}_2\) is doubled, the rate is doubled. So, the order of reaction with respect to \(\mathrm{B}_2\) is one.

Further, when concentration of A is doubled, the rate remains unaltered. So, order of reaction with respect to A is zero.

The probable rate law for the reaction will be:

\(-\frac{\mathrm{dx}}{\mathrm{dt}}=\mathrm{k}\left[\mathrm{B}_2\right][\mathrm{A}]^0=\mathrm{k}\left[\mathrm{B}_2\right]\)

Alternatively, Rate \(=\mathrm{k}\left[\mathrm{B}_2\right]^\alpha\)

\(1.6 \times 10^{-4}=\mathrm{k}[0.5]^\alpha \)

\(3.2 \times 10^{-4}=\mathrm{k}[1]^\alpha\)

On dividing we get, \(\alpha=1\)

\(\therefore\) Rate \(=\mathrm{k}[\mathrm{A}]^0\left[\mathrm{~B}_2\right]^1=\mathrm{k}\left[\mathrm{B}_2\right]\)
What happen with the rate of the reaction when the frequency and the number of effective collisions between reacting particles increases?

The atoms, ions and molecules can react to form products when they collide with enough kinetic energy and at favorable orientation. On increasing the frequency and the number of effective collisions between reacting particles increases the chance of reactants to come together to form a product that results in the increase of rate of the reaction.
What happens to the value of ΔG of a reaction when a catalyst is added to it?
It is undefined on adding a catalyst

Gibbs free energy (ΔG) is a state function, that is, it does not depend on the path taken by the reaction to reach the end product. It only depends on the enthalpy and the entropy of the reaction which in turn depend on the products and reactants of the reaction. Since a catalyst only changes the pathway taken by the reaction, it does not alter the value of ΔG.
A substance having initial concentration (a) reacts according to zero order kinetics. How much time will the reaction take to reach the completion?

For a zero order reaction, \(\left[\mathrm{A}_0\right]-[\mathrm{A}]=\mathrm{Kt}\)

When the reaction is complete, \([\mathrm{A}]=0\)

\(\left[\mathrm{A}_0\right]-[\mathrm{A}]=\left[\mathrm{A}_0\right]-0=\left[\mathrm{A}_0\right]=\mathrm{Kt}_{\text {completion }}\)

\(\mathrm{t}_{\text {completion }}=\frac{\left[\mathrm{A}_0\right]}{\mathrm{K}}=\frac{\mathrm{a}}{\mathrm{K}}\)
The order and molecularity of the chain reaction, \(\mathrm{H}_2(g)+\mathrm{Cl}_2(g) \stackrel{h v}{\longrightarrow}\) \(2 \mathrm{HCl}(g)\), are:

The given reaction is a photochemical reaction. The order of this reaction is zero as the rate is independent of the concentrations of hydrogen and chlorine.

Molecularity is the no. of molecules that come together to react in the elementary step. In the given reaction, 2 molecules (1 molecule each of \(\mathrm{H}_2\) and \(\mathrm{Cl}_2\) ) react to form the product. Hence, the molecularity is 2.

The activation energy for the bimolecular reaction \(\mathrm{A}+\mathrm{BC} \rightarrow \mathrm{AB}+\mathrm{C}\) is \(\mathrm{E}_0\) in the gas phase. If the reason carried out in a confined volume of \(\lambda^3\), the activation energy is expected to:

The minimum energy requirement that must be met for a chemical reaction to occur is called the activation energy. The activation energy depends on nature of the reacting species or reactants. It does not depends on volume that is it will remain constant irrespective of the volume.
The maximum value of activation energy is equal to:

Activation energy may be greater than heat of reaction or lesser than threshold energy. At room temperature, most of the molecules have less than the threshold value. Hence, if energy is supplied to the reactant molecules in the form of light or heat, they absorb that energy and reach a higher energy level which is equal to or greater than the threshold energy level, is called as activation energy.

Activation energy \(\left(E_a\right)=\) Threshold energy - Average kinetic energy of molecules
In 32 minutes, 75% of a first order reaction was found to be complete. When will 50% of the same reaction be complete?

The first order reaction can be

\(t=\frac{2.303}{k} \log \frac{a}{a-x}\)

we have given

\(t=32\)

let \(a=100\)

\(x=75\)

thus putting the value in above equation

\(32=\frac{2.303}{k} \log \frac{100}{100-75} \)

\(32=\frac{2.303}{k} \log \frac{100}{25} \)

\(32=\frac{2.303}{k} \log 4 \)

\(k=\frac{2.303}{32} \log 4 \)

\(k=0.07196 \log 4 \)

\(k=0.07196 \times 0.6020 \)

\(k=0.0433\)

Half - time reaction of first order can be given by

\(t_{\frac{1 }{ 2}}=\frac{0.693}{k}\)

\(t_{\frac{1 }{ 2}}=\frac{0.693}{0.0433}=16\)

The reaction \({A} \rightarrow {B}\) follows first order kinetics. The time taken for \(0.8\) mole of \({A}\) to produce \(0.6\) mole of \(B\) is 1 hour. What is the time taken for conversion of \(0.9\) mole of \(A\) to produce \(0.675\) mole of \(B\)?

Rate constant of first order reaction:

\(k=\frac{2.303}{t} \log _{10} \frac{(A)_0}{(A)_t}\)

or \(k=\frac{2.303}{1} \times \log _{10} \frac{0.8}{0.2} \)     .....(i)

(because 0.6 mole of B is formed)

Suppose \(t_1\) hour are required for changing the concentration of \(A\) from \(0.9\) mole to \(0.675\) mole of \(B\).

Remaining mole of \(A=0.9-0.675=0.225\)

\(\therefore k=\frac{2.303}{t_1} \log _{10} \frac{0.9}{0.225} \)     .....(ii)

From equation (i) and (ii)

\(\frac{2.303}{1} \log _{10} \frac{0.8}{0.2}=\frac{2.303}{t_1} \log _{10} \frac{0.9}{0.225}\)

\(2.303 \log _{10} 4=\frac{2.303}{t_1} \log _{10} 4\)

\(t_1=1 \mathrm{~h}\)

In a first order reaction, the concentration of product '\(x\)' at time '\(t\)' is given by the expression:

(where, \(\mathrm{a}=\) initial concentration, \(\mathrm{k}=\) rate constant, \(\mathrm{n}=\) order)

The integrated rate law for the first order reaction is \([\mathrm{A}]=[\mathrm{A}]_{0} e^{-k t}\)

Substituting the value of \([\mathrm{A}]=a-x\) and \([\mathrm{A}]_{0}=a\) in the above expression.

We get, \(a-x=a e^{-k t}\)

Rearrange above expression, \(x=a\left(1-e^{-k t}\right)\)
At room temperature the reaction between \(\mathrm{NO}\) and \(\mathrm{O}_2\) to give \(\mathrm{NO}_2\) is fast while that of between \(\mathrm{CO}\) and \(\mathrm{O}_2\) is slow. It is because:
CO is smaller in size than that of NO
The activation energy for the reaction \(2 \mathrm{NO}+\mathrm{O}_2 \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{NO}_2\) is less than \(2 \mathrm{CO}+\) \(\mathrm{O}_2 \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{CO}_2\)
The activation energy for the reaction \(2 \mathrm{CO}+\mathrm{O}_2 \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{CO}_2\) is less than \(2 \mathrm{NO}+\) \(\mathrm{O}_2 \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{NO}_2\)

The reaction between \(N O\) and oxygen has lower activation energy than the reaction between \(\mathrm{CO}\) and oxygen.

So, the reaction between \(N O\) and oxygen is fast whereas the reaction between CO and oxygen is slow.
The rate of chemical reaction becomes double for every 10° rise in temperature because of
Increase in number of collisions between molecules having energy greater than activation energy

With increase in temperature molecular collisions increases therefore rate of reaction doubles. With every 10° rise in temperature, the number of molecules which bring about the chemical reaction become double, so rate of chemical reaction also double.
With respect to the figure which of the following statement is correct?
\(E_A\) for reverse reaction is greater than \(E_A\) for forward reaction
\(E_A\) for forward reaction is greater than \(E_A\) for backward reaction

The activation energy for the backward reaction is equal to the sum of the activation energy of the forward reaction and the enthalpy change of the reaction. Thus the activation energy for the backward reaction is greater than the activation energy for forward reaction.

Direction: Read the following statements and choose the correct answer.

Statement 1: In a zero order reaction, if the concentration of the reactant is doubled, the half-life period is also doubled.

Statement 2: For a zero-order reaction, the rate of the reaction is independent of initial concentration.
Statement 1 is True, statement 2 is True, statement 2 is a correct explanation of statement 1
Statement 1 is True, statement 2 is True, statement 2 is not a correct explanation of statement 1

For a zero order reaction, the expression for the half life period is \(t_{\frac{1}{ 2}}=\frac{[\mathrm{A}]_0}{2 \mathrm{k}}\)

Thus half life period is directly proportional to the initial concentration. When the concentration of the reactant is doubled, the half-life period is also doubled. So, the statement 1 is true.

The rate of a zero order reaction is independent of the concentration of the reaction. The reaction proceeds at constant rate throughout. So, statement 2 is True.
Which of the following will lead to an increase in the rate of the reaction?
The presence of a catalyst in a reaction lowers the activation energy barrier and hence the reaction becomes faster. Hence, the addition of catalysts helps to increase the rate of a reaction.
What happens to the rate of the reaction on increasing its temperature?
Rate of reaction fluctuates between its maxima and minima
Rate of reaction is independent of temperature

Increasing the temperature of a reaction results in an increase in the average kinetic energy of the particles taking part in the reaction. As the kinetic energy increases, the particles move faster and collide with each other more frequently and with a higher energy. This makes it easier for chemical reactions to take place. Hence, increasing the temperature increases the rate of the reaction.
Which of the following laws state that the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of reactants?

The law of mass action is the proposition which states that the rate of a chemical reaction is directly proportional to the concentrations of the reactants. On the other hand, the other laws mentioned in the options are unrelated to the rate of a reaction.
What happens to the peak of the curve in the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution graph if temperature increases?

With the increase of temperature, the peak shifts forward but downward. This is because with the increase of temperature, the most probable kinetic energy increases and the fraction of molecules possessing most probable kinetic energy decreases.
Which of the following explains the increase in the reaction rate by a catalyst?
Catalyst decreases the rate of backward reaction so that rate of forward reaction increases
Catalyst provides extra energy to reacting molecules so that they produce effective collisions
Catalyst provides an alternative path of lower activation energy to the reactants
Catalyst increases the number of collisions between the reacting molecules.

It is because when the activation energy (Ea) is lower in a reaction, more number of reactant particles have enough energy to react and form products. Hence, it provides an alternative path and the reactions tend to occur faster.
Which of the following compounds has the highest boiling point?

For the same alkyl group, the boiling point of haloalkanes decreases in the order RI > RBr > RCl > RF. This is due to the increase in van der Waals forces when the size and mass of the halogen atom increases.

The boiling point increases with the increase in the molecular mass of the compound. Hence n-propyl iodide will have maximum boiling point among the given compounds.
Among the following, density is highest for:

Density is highest for \(\mathrm{CH}_3 \mathrm{I}\).

Density increases as molecular weight increases. Since, iodide has the highest molecular weight among \(\mathrm{F, Cl, Br}\) and \(\mathrm{I}\), it has the highest density.

Molecular weight of \(\mathrm{F, Cl, Br}\) and \(\mathrm{I}\) are \(\mathrm{18.998403~ u, 35.453~ u, 79.904 ~u}\) and \(\mathrm{126.90447~ u}\) respectively.

Arrange the following compounds in increasing order of their boiling points.

I. \(\mathrm{CH}_3 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{Br}\)

II. \(\mathrm{CH}_3 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{Br}\)

III. \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_3\right)_2 \mathrm{CHCH}_2 \mathrm{Br}\)

IV. \(\left(\mathrm{CH}_3\right)_3 \mathrm{CBr}\)

The boiling point increases as the number of carbon atoms in the carbon chain increases.

Among isomer alkyl halides boiling point decreases with the increase in branching in the alkyl group, because with branching the molecule attains a special shape with less surface area.

Thus the order of boiling points is: \(\mathrm{CH}_3 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{Br}<\left(\mathrm{CH}_3\right)_3 \mathrm{CBr}<\left(\mathrm{CH}_3\right)_2 \mathrm{CHCH}_2 \mathrm{Br}<\mathrm{CH}_3 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{Br}\)
The IUPAC name of the given structure is:

The IUPAC name of the given structure is 2-chloroacetophenone. 2-chloroacetophenone appears as a white crystalline solid. Denser than water and insoluble in water. Therefore it sinks in water. It is lachrymator, and vapors are very irritating to the eyes. It has as a floral odor. It is used as a riot control agent.
Which of the following compounds is an allyl bromide?

C3H5Br is an allyl bromide. Allyl Bromide is also known as 3-Bromo-1-propene, 3-Bromopropylene, 3-Bromopropene, 1-Propene, 3-bromo-, Bromallylene, 3-bromoprop-1-ene, Propene with Molecular Formula of C3H5Br and Molecular Weight of 120.9758.

What are the end products of the reaction given below as per Groove's process?

Ethanol \(+\mathrm{HCl} \rightarrow\)
Groove's method is used for the preparation of:

Grove's process occurs when primary alcohol or secondary alcohol is combined with \(\mathrm{HCl}\) gas in the presence of anhydrous \(\mathrm{ZnCl}_2\) to produce primary and secondary alkyl chloride or chloro-alkane. This reaction follows \(\mathrm{SN}_2\) mechanism.

For example: Ethanol reacts with hydrogen chloride to form chloroethane and water.

\(\mathrm{C}_2 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{OH}+\mathrm{HCl} \ce{->[anhydrous][Zncl2]} \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}+\mathrm{C}_2 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{Cl}\) is known as Grove's process.
The formation of two chlorine radicals from a chlorine molecule is an example of:

Homolytic fission (sometimes referred to as hemolysis) is a type of bond fission that involves the dissociation of a given molecule wherein one electron is retained by each of the original fragments of the molecule. Therefore, when a neutrally charged molecule is subjected to homolytic fission, two free radicals are obtained as the product (since each of the chemical species retains one electron from the bond pair).

Which of the following rules states that during the addition across unsymmetrical double bond, the negative part of the attacking reagent attaches itself to the carbon atom carrying lesser number of hydrogen atoms?

Markovnikov's rule states that when an asymmetrical reagent is added to an asymmetrical alkene, then the negative half of the reagent will attach to the carbon atom containing fewer hydrogen atoms.

According to Markovnikov rule, the hydrogen atom is attached to the carbon atom with the highest number of hydrogen substituents.

Anti-Markovnikov Rule: According to Anti Markovnikov rule, the hydrogen atom is attached to the carbon atom with the least number of hydrogen substituents.
Reaction of \(\mathrm{HBr}\) with propene in the presence of peroxide gives:

According to Markovnikov's rule, negative part of addendum (adding molecule) gets attached to that doubly bonded \(\mathrm{C}\) which posses lower number of hydrogen atoms. In presence of peroxide, \(\mathrm{HBr}\) adds on alkenes in antimarkovnikov's way, thus

\(\mathrm{H}_3 \mathrm{C}-\underset{\text { Propene }}{\mathrm{CH}}=\mathrm{CH}_2+\mathrm{HBr} \stackrel{\text { Peroxide }}{\rightarrow} \underset{\text { n-propyl bromide }}{\mathrm{H}_3 \mathrm{C}-\mathrm{CH}_2-\mathrm{CH}_2 \mathrm{Br}}\)

Kharasch observed that the addition of \(\mathrm{HBr}\) to unsymmetrical alkene in the presence of organic peroxide follows an opposite course to that suggested by Markovnikov. This is termed anti-Markovnikov or peroxide effect.
Flourobenzene \(\left(\mathrm{C}_6 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{~F}\right)\) can be synthesised in the laboratory:
from aniline by diazotisation followed by heating the diazonium salt with \(\mathrm{HBF}_4\)
by direct fluorination of benzene with \(\mathrm{F}_2\) gas

Fluorobenzene \(\left(\mathrm{C}_6 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{~F}\right)\) can be synthesized in the laboratory from aniline by diazotisation followed by heating the diazonium salt with \(\mathrm{HBF}_4\). The reaction is called Balz-Schiemann reaction.
When alkyl halide is heated with dry \(\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O}\), it produces ______.

Alkyl halide on reaction with dry silver oxide gives ether.

When alkyl halide is treated with dry \(\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O}\) in the presence of heat, then it will give ether and silver halide act as a by-product. The reaction is shown below:

\(\underset{\text { Alkyl halide }}{2 \mathrm{RX}}+\mathrm{Ag}_2 \mathrm{O} \rightarrow \underset{\text { ether }}{\mathrm{R}}-\mathrm{O}-\mathrm{R}+2 \mathrm{AgX}\)

Only primary alkyl halides are best because they give primarily substitution reactions (ether formation).
On reduction any aldehyde gives secondary alcohol
Reaction of vegetable oil with \(\mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{SO}_4\) gives glycerine
Sucrose on reaction with \(\mathrm{NaCl}\) gives invert sugar

When Iodine and sodium hydroxide are added to a compound that contains either a methyl ketone or a secondary alcohol with a methyl group in the alpha position, a pale yellow precipitate of iodoform or triiodomethane is formed. It can be used to identify aldehydes or ketones.

\(\mathrm{C}_2 \mathrm{H}_5 \mathrm{OH}+4 \mathrm{I}_2+6 \mathrm{NaOH} \rightarrow \underset{\text { iodoform }}{\mathrm{CHI}_3 \downarrow}+\mathrm{HCOONa}+5 \mathrm{NaI}+5 \mathrm{H}_2 \mathrm{O}\)
The addition of \(\mathrm{HCl}\) to vinyl chloride gives 1,1-dichloroethane because of?
It is an addition reaction and product is direct by Markownikoff's rule.
1-Phenyl-2-chloropropane when treated with alcoholic KOH gives  _______________ as the major product.
1-Phenyl-2-chloropropane when treated with alcoholic KOH gives 1-Phenylpropene as the major product.
In a coordination entity of the type [PtCl2(en)2]2+ which isomer will show optical isomerism?

In a coordination entity of the type [PtCl2(en)2]2+ cis-isomer isomer will show optical isomerism.

In octahedral complexes containing didentate ligands, optical isomerism is common. In a coordination entity of the type [PtCl2(en)2]2+, only the cis-isomer shows optical activity.

We can see that in the cis isomer the mirror images are non-superimposable whereas in trans-isomer the mirror images will be superimposable and hence will not show optical activity.

The reaction \(\mathrm{RX}+2 \mathrm{Na}+\mathrm{RX} \longrightarrow \mathrm{R}-\mathrm{R}+2 \mathrm{NaX}\) is called Wurtz reaction.

The Wurtz reaction is a very useful reaction in the fields of organic chemistry and organometallic chemistry for the formation of alkanes. In this reaction, two different alkyl halides are coupled to yield a longer alkane chain with the help of sodium and dry ether solution.
AgCN reacts with haloalkanes to form isocyanide. Haloalkanes react with KCN to form alkyl cyanides as main product

AgCN is covalent in nature while KCN is ionic so KCN produces CN- in the solution.

CN- is an ambient nucleophile i.e. it can form bond from both C and N atoms. KCN is an ionic compound so both C and N sides are available for the formation of bond, but C-C bond is stronger than C-N bond so cynide is formed. AgCN is a covalent compound so only N side is available for CN to form bond and thus isocynide is formed.
The process of converting alkyl halides to alcohols involve:

Reaction with Alkyl halides:

Alkyl halides goes for two reactions - Substitution and elimination reaction.

In a substitution reaction, the X group in R-X is replaced by a different group i.e.,

\({R} .{X} \rightarrow {R}-{OH}+{X}^{+}\)

In the elimination reaction, the elements of H-X are eliminated from R-X; the product is very often alkene.

Step 1:

  • Alkyl halides form sodium phenoxide in the first step.

Step 2:

  • The phenoxide ion then takes up the Electrophile proton and results in the formation of Phenol.

The reaction takes place at boiling temperatures of NaOH at about 6000 C and 300 atm pressure.
The treatment of ethyl bromide with alcoholic silver nitrite gives:

On heating with an ethanolic solution of silver nitrite, alkyl halides yield nitroalkanes.

  • Some of the alkyl nitrites are also formed because nitrite is an ambidentate ligand.
  • It has a lone pair of electrons on nitrogen as well as oxygen.
  • Thus it can be bonded to an alkyl group of alkyl halide through oxygen to form alkyl nitrite and via Nitrogen to form nitroalkane.

The reactions take place as follows:

Thus, the treatment of ethyl bromide with alcoholic silver nitrite gives nitroethane.
Which of the following is an example of aryl alkyl halide?

An aryl halide is formed when the hydrogen atom(s) bonded to the benzene ring are replaced by a halogen atom. This can happen by direct halogenation reaction. 

Benzyl chloride,


It consists of an aromatic ring and an alkyl halide group. Thus, it can be classified as an aryl alkyl halide.
What is the general formula for haloalkanes? (X=halogen atom, n = 1, 2, 3…)
The general formula for haloalkanes is CnH2n+1X where X is a halogen atom and n = 1, 2, 3… The formulae CnH2n-1X and CnH2n-3X are that of haloalkenes and haloalkynes respectively.
The compound C6H5F is an example of a ________ halide.
In C6H5F, the F atom is directly attached to the sp2 hybridised carbon atom of an aromatic ring, i.e., benzene.
3-Bromopropene has 3 C atoms in the parent chain with a double bond at C-1 and Br at C-3. This means that Br is attached to the C which is next to the C-C double bond, hence it is an allylic halide.
What is the IUPAC name of the following compound?
The longest chain of C atoms is 4 (butene) and the numbering should begin from the Br side to satisfy the lowest set of locants rule. So, Br is at C-1 and double bond is at C-2.
Which of the following is not the correct IUPAC name for the compound shown?
All the names given are appropriate for the shown compound, but m-Chlorotoluene is the common name and not the IUPAC name.
In the common naming system, the prefix sym- is used for haloarenes with _____ halogen atoms.

The prefix sym- is used for trihaloarenes with same halogen atom at alternate positions in the benzene ring (1, 3, 5). The prefixes o-, m- and p- are used for dihaloarenes depending on the relative positions of the two identical halogen atoms on the aromatic ring.
How many carbon atoms does Isobutyl chloride have in its parent carbon chain?
The IUPAC name of Isobutyl chloride is 1-Chloro-2-methylpropane, which means the parent chain consists of 3 carbon atoms with an alkyl group at C-2 and a halogen at C-1.
What is the IUPAC name for the compound (CH3)3CCH2Cl?

There are two different possible chains that consists of maximum 3 C atoms. One of them has two methyl and one chloro group and the other has one methyl and one complex substituent. The preference is given to the former with the chloro at C-1 and the 2 methyl groups at C-2.
Fumaric acid is stronger than Maleic acid
Maleic acid is stronger than fumaric acid

Maleic acid is cis-butenedioic acid whereas fumaric acid is trans-butenedioic acid. Maleic acid is able to lose \(H^{+}\)ion and it results in the formation of intra hydrogen bond. Whereas fumaric acid being a trans isomer has strong interaction with both the oxygen atoms of each carboxylic group. Therefore, fumaric acid is unable to give hydrogen ions as compared to maleic acid.

That is why, maleic acid is stronger than fumaric acid.
Which of the following gives benzoic acid on oxidation?

Benzyl chloride gives benzoic acid on oxidation.

The reaction takes place as follows:

\(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5} \mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{Cl}+2 \mathrm{KOH}+2[\mathrm{O}] \longrightarrow \mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5} \mathrm{COOK}+\mathrm{KCl}+\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\)
Which has a smell of oil of wintergreen?

Methyl salicylate (oil of wintergreen or wintergreen oil) is an organic compound with the formula \(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{4}(\mathrm{OH})\left(\mathrm{CO}_{2} \mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)\).  It is produced by many species of plants, particularly wintergreens.
Boiling points of carbonyl compounds are higher than those of alkanes due to:

Boiling points of carbonyl compounds are higher than those of alkanes due to dipole-dipole interactions.

The boiling points of aldehydes and ketones (carbonyl compounds) are higher than boiling point of non-polar alkanes due to the presence of dipole-dipole interactions between molecules of carbonyl compounds which are much stronger than Van der Waals forces between molecules of alkanes.

What is the name of the following compound?

\(\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{CH}_{2} \mathrm{COCl}\)

Numbering the carbon atoms as: \(\mathrm{\stackrel{3}{C}H_{3}\stackrel{2}{C}H_{2}\stackrel{1}{C}OCl}\)

This is an acid chloride. It consists of three carbon atoms in the parent chain and chloroformyl group \(\mathrm{(-COCl)}\). In the IUPAC name, the suffix "oyl chloride" is added. Therefore, the IUPAC name will be propanoyl chloride.
What is the name of the above reaction?

The above reaction is known as Etard reaction.

  • The Etard Reaction is a chemical reaction that involves the direct oxidation of an aromatic or heterocyclic bound methyl group to an aldehyde using chromyl chloride. 
  • When toluene is reacted with Chromyl Chloride, then a chromium complex is formed (Etard Complex) whose hydrolysis gives Benzaldehyde.

"Acidic hydrogen means it has a tendency to be released as \(H^{+}\) ion. So, if any H-atom is attached to another atom or group of atoms with higher electronegativity, that \(\mathrm{H}\)-atom can be released very easily as \(H^{+}\) ion."

(A) 

The hydrogen marked with red color is an acidic hydrogen, due to the presence of hydrogens in between electron withdrawing groups.

(B) 

The hydrogens marked with red color are acidic hydrogens, due to the presence of hydrogens in between electron withdrawing groups.

(C) 

The hydrogen marked with red color is acidic hydrogen, due to the presence of hydrogens in between electron withdrawing groups.

(D) 

The hydrogen marked with red color is acidic hydrogen, due to the attachment of hydrogen directly to the oxygen.

Oxygen atoms have higher electronegativity than carbon.

So, the hydrogen which is attached to oxygen is more acidic than the hydrogen atoms that are attached to carbon atoms (carbon atoms later attached to electron withdrawing groups).
The correct order of increasing acidic strength is:

The correct order of increasing acidic strength is Ethanol < Phenol < Acetic acid < Chloroacetic acid.

  • Phenol is more acidic than ethanol because in phenol, the phenoxide ion obtained on deprotonation is stabilized by resonance which is not possible in case of ethanol.
  • Also carboxylic acids are more acidic than alcohols and phenols as the carboxylate ion is stabilized by resonance. Chloroacetic acid is more acidic than acetic acid due to inductive effect of chlorine atom which stabilizes the carboxylate anion.

Toluene reacts with halogen in presence of iron(III) chloride giving ortho and para halo compounds, the reaction is electrophilic substitution reaction.


The \(\mathrm{H}\) atom or aromatic nucleus is replaced with \(\mathrm{Cl}\) atom. The electrophile in this reaction is \(\mathrm{C l^{+}}\) ion obtained by the reaction of \(\mathrm{Cl}_{2}\) with \(\mathrm{AlCl}_{3}\).

Identify the product for the following reaction.

\({CH} \equiv {CH}+{HOCl} \rightarrow\)

\({HOCl} \longrightarrow {OH}^{-}+{Cl}^{+}\)

\(C l^{+}\)shall attack acetylene as an electrophile and \(O H^{-}\)will end the addition with a nucleophilic addition.

Therefore, the final reaction will be:

Presence of unsaturation in organic compounds can be tested with:

Baeyer's reagent (alk. \(\mathrm{KMnO}_{4}\) ) which is pink in colour decolourises due to the presence of unsaturation.

Thus, it shows the presence of unsaturation in an organic compound.
Ozonolysis of an organic compound gives formaldehyde as one of the products. This confirms the presence of:

Presence of one vinyl (or ethenyl) group gives formaldehyde as one of the product in ozonolysis.

CH2=CH- on ozonolysis will give HCHO.

  • Ozonolysis is an organic reaction where the unsaturated bonds of alkenes, alkynes, or azo compounds are cleaved with ozone. 
  • Alkenes and alkynes form organic compounds in which the multiple carbon–carbon bond has been replaced by a carbonyl group while azo compounds form nitrosamine.
Ionic species are stabilised by the dispersal of charge, which of the following carboxylate ions is the most positive charge?

Ionic species are stabilized by the dispersal of charge.

  • The carboxylate ion \( \left(\mathrm{F}_{2} \mathrm{CHCOO}^{-}\right)\)is the most stable.
  • The negative charge on \(\mathrm{O}\) is dispersed through resonance in the carboxylate group.
  • The negative charge is further dispersed due to negative inductive effect (-I effect) of two \(\mathrm{F}\) atoms present on alpha carbon atoms.

Which of the following names is correct for \(\mathrm{\underset { \overset { | }{ CHO }  }{ { CH }_{ 2 } } -\underset { \overset { | }{ CHO }  }{ CH } -\underset { \overset { | }{ CHO }  }{ { CH }_{ 2 } }}\)?

Numbering the carbon atoms, we get: \(\mathrm{\underset { \overset { | }{ CHO }  }{ { \overset {3}{C}H }_{ 2 } } -\underset { \overset { | }{ CHO }  }{\overset {2}{C}H } -\underset { \overset { | }{ CHO }  }{ { \overset {1}{C}H }_{ 2 } }}\)

Since there are three carbon atoms in long chain and it contains 3 -CHO groups (one on each carbon atom). IUPAC suffix "aldehyde" will added due to presence of functional group -CHO.

Therefore, the correct IUPAC name will be propane-1, 2, 3-tricarbaldehyde.
The oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde by chromyl chloride is called:

The oxidation of toluene \(\left(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{3} \mathrm{CH}_{3}\right)\) with chromyl chloride \(\left(\mathrm{CRO}_{2} \mathrm{Cl}_{2}\right)\) in \(\mathrm{CCl}_{4}\) or \(C S_{2}\) to give benzaldehyde is called Etard reaction.  In this reaction, the chromyl chloride first forms a brown complex, which is seperated and then decomposed with \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) to give benzaldehyde \(\left(\mathrm{C}_{6} \mathrm{H}_{5} \mathrm{CHO}\right)\).
There is a large difference in the boiling points of butanal and butan-1-ol due to:

There is a large difference in the boiling points of butanal and butan-1-ol due to intermolecular hydrogen bonding in butan-1-ol.  Butan-1-ol has polar O-H bond due to which it shows intermolecular H-bonding which is not possible in case of butanal due to absence of polar bond.
Which among the following is most reactive to give nucleophilic addition?
\(\mathrm{FCH}_{2} \mathrm{CHO}\) is most reactive towards nucleophilic addition since presence of most electronegative \(F\) withdraws electron from carbon of carbonyl group making it more polar.

n-Butane has more boiling point than acetone
Methanal and propanone are immiscible with water in all proportions

  • Lower Aldehydes are pungent but higher Aldehydes are fragrant.
  • Acetone is more polar than n-Butane and weight is comparable, so acetone has higher boiling point.
  • Methanal is soluble in water.
Order of esterification strength of alcohols is?
Order of reactivity of different alcohols towards esterification is \(1^{\circ}>2^{\circ}>3^{\circ}\) alcohol due to increased steric hinderance in \(2^{\circ}\) and \(3^{\circ}\) alcohols.
Which of the following compounds will undergo Cannizzaro reaction?

Aldehydes with no \(\alpha\) - \(H\) atom undergo Cannizzaro reaction on Heating with conc. alkali solution.

Which of the following carboxylic acid is highly insoluble in water?

Higher carboxylic acids are insoluble in water due to the increased hydrophobic interaction of the hydrocarbon part. 

  • Thus, decanoic acid is highly insoluble in water, as it contains longer hydrocarbon chain.
  • Decanoic acid is a ten-carbon, saturated fatty acid. It is present in palm kernel, coconut fat and in milk fat.

Carboxylic acids form dimers by hydrogen bonding of the acidic hydrogen and the carbonyl oxygen when anhydrous. Due to the small size and strong hydrogen bonding between the molecule (intermolecular), they overlap and form a dimer in aqueous condition. For example, acetic acid forms a dimer in the gas phase, where the monomer units are held together by hydrogen bonds.

The addition of \(H C N\) to carbonyl compounds is an example of:
